content: A large class of subcategories of the presheaf category are given by cocompleting the category freely under some class of colimits. Examples of this include Cauchy completion (absolute colimits), coproduct completion, Ind completion (filtered colimits), and sifted colimit completions. There is an explicit representation of these cocompletion: given some class ϕ\phiϕ, the free cocompletion under those colimits is Flatϕc[Cop,Set]\mathrm{Flat}_{\phi^c}[C^{op}, \mathrm{Set}]Flatϕc​[Cop,Set], where ϕc\phi^cϕc is a certain "conjugate/complement" class to ϕ\phiϕ and "flat" denotes a ϕc\phi^cϕc-limit preserving functor that also preserves these limits even when they don't exist. If CCC already has all ϕc\phi^cϕc colimits, then the free ϕ\phiϕ-cocompletion is just Limϕc[Cop,Set]\mathrm{Lim}_{\phi^c}[C^{op}, \mathrm{Set}]Limϕc​[Cop,Set].

For instance, for ind completion, ϕ\phiϕ is filtered colimits and ϕc\phi^cϕc is finite limits, so the notion of ϕc\phi^cϕc flatness is just the usual notion of flatness. For sifted colimits, ϕc\phi^cϕc is finite products. The free cocompletion itself is also a special case- if ϕ\phiϕ is all colimits, then ϕc\phi^cϕc must be absolute limits, and any presheaf preserves those (even the absolute limits that don't exist). But in all examples I have with explicit characterizations of ϕc\phi^cϕc, ϕ\phiϕ-colimits both distribute AND commute with ϕc\phi^cϕc-limits in Set\mathrm{Set}Set, making it difficult to determine which one of these two is the actual correct characterization of the class ϕc\phi^cϕc, since commutativity and distributivity diverge in general.
So my question is: what is the correct characterization of ϕc\phi^cϕc: is it the class of limits that commute with ϕ\phiϕ-colimits in Set\mathrm{Set}Set, or those that distribute with them? Thanks!
Perhaps https://rezk.web.illinois.edu/accessible-cat-thoughts.pdf and the references therein might be useful.

Fernando Yamauti said:

Perhaps https://rezk.web.illinois.edu/accessible-cat-thoughts.pdf and the references therein might be useful.

Thanks! This work seems highly informative too for some of the other things I'm curious about.
Based on the section for "regular classes", it seems the criteria is that the colimit functor on diagrams in class ϕ\phiϕ preserve ϕc\phi^cϕc limits, which is the notion of commutativity of limits and colimits. So the answer to my question is "commutativity", not "distributivity".
Edit: Actually what I was thinking of was not the regular classes section, but the paper's definition of FiltU\mathrm{Filt}_UFiltU​ for some class of limits UUU. But the result is the same!
“Distributivity” is still a not-too-well-studied concept I think; commutativity is usually going to be the answer to a question like this.

I have a follow up question to this. The article states that if DDD has filtered colimits, C→DC \to DC→D is a fully faithful inclusion into the presentable objects of DDD, and CCC generates DDD under filtered colimits, then D≅Ind(C)D \cong \mathrm{Ind}(C)D≅Ind(C). It also states the subcategory of Ind(C)\mathrm{Ind}(C)Ind(C) on presentable objects are precisely the retracts of CCC (IE, the idempotent completion of CCC). But the article doesn't address the converse- for instance, perhaps it's also possible for a non-equivalent category to the ind completion to have its presentable objects equivalent to the idempotent completion of CCC.

Let DDD be a category with filtered colimits and a dense subcategory C→DC \to DC→D, such that DDD also contains the idempotent completion of CCC. Is it true that if the full subcategory of DDD on presentable objects is precisely the idempotent completion of CCC, then automatically D≅Ind(C)D \cong \mathrm{Ind}(C)D≅Ind(C)?
Are you perhaps missing the fact that idempotent splittings are filtered colimits?

Kevin Carlson said:

Are you perhaps missing the fact that idempotent splittings are filtered colimits?

Hmm, in that case, the Cauchy completion of CCC would be expressed as filtered colimits of objects of CCC in DDD. But I'm not sure how that extends to showing all of DDD is generated under filtered colimit of objects of CCC.
No, that doesn't resolve your question, it just makes one of your assumptions automatic which was otherwise making me feel awkward.

I think you can probably cut out the nontrivial finite colimits of representables from a category of presheaves on an idempotent complete category without breaking existence of filtered colimits, because [intuitively, I don't know how to make this precise] the only interesting finite filtered colimits are idempotent splittings.

Oh, maybe I do know; if CCC is a finite filtered category, then by definition its identity functor has a cocone α\alphaα with tip some object t.t.t. The component αt:t→t\alpha_t:t\to tαt​:t→t is idempotent by the cocone condition, and one can check that the corresponding functor from the walking idempotent is final.

Kevin Carlson said:

No, that doesn't resolve your question, it just makes one of your assumptions automatic which was otherwise making me feel awkward.

Ah, I see, I didn't have to add the extra assumption that the idempotent completion of the category also embeds.

After doing some more work with help from your hints above, I've derived a relatively simple counter-example to my claim and therefore showed it to be false. Here's the basics. By a partial result in the paper, if CCC embeds fully faithfully into the compact objects of DDD a category with filtered colimits, then the canonical functor Ind(C)→D\mathrm{Ind}(C) \to DInd(C)→D via the universal property of Ind is fully faithful. By density of CCC we derive a chain of inclusions: Ind(C)→D→Psh(C)\mathrm{Ind}(C) \to D \to \mathrm{Psh}(C)Ind(C)→D→Psh(C). So DDD is just an enlargement of the ind completion in presheaves, therefore, if we find such an enlargement that doesn't change the compact objects of the ind completion (which are already precisely the retracts of representables), we have an example of a non-equivalent category to ind which satisfies my criteria.

Your suggestion above made me remember that the compact objects of presheaves are the finite colimits of representables. Thus, if DDD includes any of those, we've added in a new compact object and so we indeed change the compact objects of the category. But the solution is simple: take the ind completion and add in just a single infinite colimit of representables, and let that be DDD. This isn't a compact object in presheaves, and therefore adding it does not in fact change the compact objects of CCC. Hence, it is a counterexample and the above "conjecture" is false.
The correspondence I think you are trying to get only works for loc pres cat: it's Gabriel-Ulmer duality (also in the context of sound doctrines).

Also you must be careful about splitting idempotents since, for 1-cats, finite (co)limits are enough (and, therefore, you won't see the requirement of being idemp complete in the classical case of the duality), but, in the higher case, you need, at least, sequential colimits.

Fernando Yamauti said:

The correspondence I think you are trying to get only works for loc pres cat: it's Gabriel-Ulmer duality (also in the context of sound doctrines).

That's really interesting that Gabriel-Ulmer duality comes up in relation to the connection between filtered colimits and finite limits. But I guess it makes some sense- when CCC has finite limits, then the action of taking the subcategory of presheaves that preserve finite limits is exactly the action of cocompleting under filtered colimits. From the article, it looks like more generally, when ϕ\phiϕ is a sound doctrine, then if CCC has all ϕ\phiϕ limits then taking the subcategory of presheaves that preserve them is the act of cocompleting under the colimits that commute with ϕ\phiϕ limits in Set\mathrm{Set}Set.

The real surprise is then that there's a functor going the opposite way constituting an equivalence- that you can start with a "presentable category" for some class of colimits (IE, filtered in the usual case) and uniquely recover the cauchy complete category that it is the cocompletion of under that class of colimits. So this indeed reveals that the precise extra criteria to make my above statement work is for DDD to be locally presentable.

In the free coproduct construction of CCC, the objects can be thought of as families of objects of CCC. So there might be a relation between Coprod(C)\mathrm{Coprod}(C)Coprod(C) and the comma category (Set/C)(\mathrm{Set}/C)(Set/C), with Set\mathrm{Set}Set the subcategory of Cat\mathrm{Cat}Cat on discrete categories. In another case, the free filtered colimit construction of CCC has objects that you can think of as filtered diagrams in CCC. So there's some relation between Ind(C)\mathrm{Ind}(C)Ind(C) and (Filt/C)(\mathrm{Filt}/C)(Filt/C) with Filt\mathrm{Filt}Filt being the subcategory of Cat\mathrm{Cat}Cat on filtered categories.

When generalizing to the free cocompletion under all diagrams, we thus expect there to be a relation between [Cop,Set][C^{op}, \mathrm{Set}][Cop,Set] and (Cat/C)(\mathrm{Cat}/C)(Cat/C). While these aren't equivalent, this relation can actually be restricted to an equivalence between presheaves on CCC and discrete fibrations into CCC using the Grothendieck construction. This is a reflection of how the canonical colimit describing a presheaf is a colimit over its category of elements, the discrete fibration.

So my question: is there any connection with the idea of the Grothendieck construction at the heart of the ability to interpret the objects of the free coproduct completion and ind completion as families and filtered diagrams in CCC respectively? And in general, given some arbitrary class of colimits ϕ\phiϕ, what is the full general form of the correspondence between functors into CCC from ϕ\phiϕ categories and objects of the free ϕ\phiϕ cocompletion of CCC?
